column1: City of God (Portuguese: Cidade de Deus) is a 1997 semi-autobiographical novel by Paulo Lins
column2: about three young men and their lives in Cidade de Deus
column3: a favela in Western Rio de Janeiro where Lins grew up. It is the only novel by Lins that has been published. It took Lins 10 years to complete the book. The novel was hailed by critics as one of the greatest works of contemporary Brazilian literature.

column1: It was made into a feature film of the same name in 2002
column2: which went on to be nominated for four Oscars. An English translation of the book was published in 2006. Thanks to the international recognition of the film
column3: the book continued to be translated into several more languages

column1: The book is named after the Favela in which the novel takes place
column2: Cidade de Deus. Cidade de Deus was established in 1960 in the western zone of Rio de Janeiro as part of a government strategy to systematically move favelas away from the city centre and relocate inhabitants to the suburbs.

column1: City of God is set in a city renowned for its natural beauty. The novel follows the lives of gangsters and petty criminals living in the Favela. The novel is set from the 1960s through to the 1980s. In the beginning
column2: delinquents make money  through hold-ups. In the 1970's
column3: cocaine arrives and takes its place in  the criminals' lives
column4: both dealing and consuming vast amounts. Drug lords use their wealth to buy guns
column5: which give them more power. Conflicts over who controls the drug trade in the Favela result in gang wars. Written laws do not apply; power is held by criminals and drug lords who rule the Favela. The poorly paid police monitor the gangs
column6: not for the sake of public safety
column7: but to ensure their corrupt income from the gangs.
